newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Yeltsin, premier discuss budget, social issues.
newsitem.headline: Yeltsin, premier discuss budget, social issues.

text.p: President Boris Yeltsin, ruling Russia from a sanatorium where he is awaiting heart surgery, on Tuesday discussed a range of issues including plans for the 1997 budget with Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin.
Russian news agencies said economic, social and international issues as well as the key unresolved question of next year's budget figured in discussions between the two men.
Parliament rejected draft 1997 spending plans last week complaining that revenue forecasts were hopelessly optimistic.
A special commission examining how to rake in much-needed tax arrears was to hold its first meeting on Tuesday.
The VChK commission has the same initials in Russian as the Soviet-era secret police of Felix Dzerzhinsky and many Russians expect it to clamp down on tax evaders in a draconian way.
One official, quoted by Itar-Tass news agency, said company bosses could be held personally responsible if tax bills were not paid.

The 65-year-old Kremlin leader, anxious to avert political confrontation at a crucial time, on Monday asked Chernomyrdin, chief-of-staff Anatoly Chubais and parliamentary chiefs to work together while he gets ready for a heart bypass operation.
"We cannot have people running in different directions and solving questions in their own ways," he said.

U.S. cardiologist Michael DeBakey, who is advising the Russian doctors on Yeltsin's operation, said in a newspaper interview published on Tuesday that Yeltsin's condition was improving and surgery would go ahead as planned.

"If there are no complications -- and I repeat, there are none right now -- the operation will take place at the end of November, during the last two weeks of the month," DeBakey told the Italian daily Corriere della Sera.
Yeltsin made his plea for compromise and cooperation after sacking security chief Alexander Lebed last Thursday and bringing in a moderate as secretary of the influential security council.
The new group, the "permanent four", gives administration chief Anatoly Chubais a far bigger role in the affairs of state.
Lebed's sudden dismissal ignited fears that a bloody war in breakaway Chechnya might resume. Lebed was the architect of a fragile peace deal that halted 21 months of fighting there.
But there have been no reports of clashes in the Caucasus region and separatist leaders have indicated that they are ready to work with Lebed's successor, Ivan Rybkin.
Rybkin, the former speaker of the State Duma lower house of parliament, also replaces the gruff ex-paratroop commander as Yeltsin's personal envoy to the southern region.
"Rybkin and Lebed are different people but we won't link the results of the peace process with personalities," rebel leader Zelimkhan Yandarbiyev told Russian television on Monday.
But Rybkin made clear on Tuesday that he would adopt a different style from Lebed, who won a reputation for acting first and thinking about it later.
"I disliked cavalry attacks from childhood," Rybkin told the Vecharnaya Moskva newspaper.

Lebed's peace accord is deeply unpopular in the Duma, which is dominated by hardline communists and nationalists who see it as a humiliating capitulation to the rebels that will trigger the disintegration of the Russian Federation.
